intro: Gilia leptantha subsp. transversa, commonly known as the Transversa Gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and showy, violet-blue flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or open habitats, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The species is notable for its ecological adaptability and is sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value.
